[[File:Ascame Associacion de Cambras de Comercio del Mediterráneo.jpg|thumb|right]]
The '''Association of the Mediterranean Chambers of Commerce and Industry''', in abbreviated form '''ASCAME''', is an organisation of international scope, of a voluntary, non-profit making nature. It unites the Chambers of Commerce and Industry and other similar institutions of the countries of the [[Mediterranean basin]], and works on the assumption that the [[Black Sea]] is a natural extension of the [[Mediterranean Sea]].<ref>[http://www.ascame.org/c/document_library/get_file?folderId=110459&name=DLFE-804.pdf ASCAME Statute] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120328075847/http://www.ascame.org/c/document_library/get_file?folderId=110459&name=DLFE-804.pdf |date=March 28, 2012 }}</ref>
ASCAME was formed on 1 October 1982. The Constitutive General Assembly was held in Barcelona, hosted by the Barcelona Chamber of Commerce, Industry and Navigation. It is an Organization with a potential membership of 500 Chambers of Commerce, and other associated entities, from the 23 countries bordering the Mediterranean Sea.
Today, ASCAME is the most important representative of the Mediterranean private sector with over 250 Chambers of Commerce from the 23 countries of the Mediterranean basin. ASCAME is a well-consolidated entity that represents the interest of the Mediterranean Chambers of Commerce and the Private Sector, also being accredited as an economic partner of the EU and international organizations in carrying out economic cooperation projects. ASCAME represents all North and South chambers and business regardless of their size and sector of activity.
==History==
The Association of the Mediterranean Chambers of Commerce and Industry – ASCAME – was founded on October 1, 1982, as an initiative of the Barcelona Chamber of Commerce in conjunction with its counterparts from different Mediterranean countries, and in 1994 it was transformed in an International Association, on the initiative of the Chamber of Commerce of Marseille. From the about ten founding member of 1982, today ASCAME brings together over two hundred Chambers of Commerce and similar institutions, from twenty-two Mediterranean countries: [[Albania]], [[Algeria]], [[Bosnia & Herzegovina]], [[Bulgaria]], [[Cyprus]], [[Croatia]], [[Egypt]], [[France]], [[Greece]], [[Italy]], [[Jordan]], [[Lebanon]], [[Libya]], [[Republic of Macedonia|Macedonia]], [[Malta]], [[Montenegro]], [[Morocco]], [[Serbia]], [[Spain]], [[Syria]], [[Tunisia]] and [[Turkey]].<ref>[http://images.ca.camcom.gov.it/f/Sardegnaeconomica/n./n.32001b.pdf What is ASCAME] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120328075845/http://images.ca.camcom.gov.it/f/Sardegnaeconomica/n./n.32001b.pdf |date=March 28, 2012 }}</ref>
ASCAME was created with the primary goal of furthering economic cooperation throughout the Mediterranean region, showing a strategic vision of North-South cooperation and integration. This vision was confirmed by the establishment of the Euro-Mediterranean Partnership in 1995 and is validated today by the Union for the Mediterranean.
==Objectives==
According to article 3 of the Statutes, “''The fundamental purpose of this Association is to establish permanent contacts andforge lasting relationships among its members in order to co-ordinate, implement andpromote studies and joint actions with a view to developing economic exchanges andco-operation within the Mediterranean area of international scope.''”
The objectives that the association wants to achieve are:
• The creation of a network of Chambers of Commerce and organisations working in the field of cooperation and economic exchange between countries in the Mediterranean region.
• Promotion of and search for synergies between these countries' economies.
• The creation of working ties between peer institutions aimed at encouraging international cooperation through joint performance of activities and/or studies.
• Assertion of the Mediterranean identity.
• Contribution to create an area of peace, tolerance, security and prosperity.
==Members==
As a result of amendments approved by the Extraordinary General Assembly of Tunis of May 2001, the Association envisages two types of membership: ''Full Members'', all the Chambers of Commerce of the Mediterranean countries, and ''Associate Members'', which are the various Mediterranean institutions and organizations having a relationship with the objectives of ASCAME.
Currently, [https://web.archive.org/web/20120328080112/http://www.ascame.org/members ASCAME members] include:
1 Chamber of Commerce from Albania
18 Chambers of Commerce from Algeria
1 Chamber of Commerce from Bosnia & Herzegovina
1 Chamber of Commerce from Bulgaria
1 Chamber of Commerce from Cyprus
4 Chambers of Commerce from Croatia
11 Chambers of Commerce from Egypt
18 Chambers of Commerce from France
11 Chambers of Commerce from Greece
38 Chambers of Commerce from Italy
1 Chamber of Commerce from Jordanian
6 Chambers of Commerce from Lebanon
1 Chamber of Commerce from Libya
1 Chamber of Commerce from Macedonia
1 Chamber of Commerce from Malta
1 Chamber of Commerce from Montenegro
32 Chambers of Commerce from Morocco
1 Chamber of Commerce from Serbia
24 Chambers of Commerce from Spain
7 Chambers of Commerce from Syria
14 Chambers of Commerce from Tunisia
16 Chambers of Commerce from Turkey
==Organisation==
ASCAME's operating structure consists of:
- the ''General Assembly'': composed of all members, it defines the general policy and major lines of activity of the Association
- the ''Executive Committee'': the permanent management and administration body of ASCAME
- the ''Bureau'', which acts on behalf of the Executive Committee as regards ordinary and ongoing matters
- the ''General Secretariat'', which is responsible for monitoring the decisions taken by the General Meeting, the Executive Committee and the Bureau, conserving ASCAME records and providing secretarial services
- the ''Commissions''
- the ''Working Groups''.
===The Commissions===
The ASCAME Commissions are created by the Executive Committee in order to achieve the ASCAME objectives. There are in total 16 Commissions, each chaired by a member of ASCAME. A Commission may be composed of members of the Association, as well as of other experts, who may be invited to participate in the Commissions' meetings and activities.
The Commissions are:
Tourism Commission
Culture and Intellectual Property Commission
International Relations Commission
Training Commission
Logistics and Transport Commission
Urban Infrastructures Commission
Business Cooperation Commission
Environment and Climate Change Commission
Industry Commission
Women Entrepreneurs Commission
Arbitration Commission
Investment Commission
Innovation and ICT Commission
Renewable Energy Commission
Young Entrepreneur Commission
==Activities==
ASCAME provides support and advice to the Chamber of Commerce members, encourages contacts between them and promotes their respective initiatives, such as staff exchange programmes between Chambers of Commerce members, training programmes, forums, conventions and fairs. The Association plays a significant role in the field of international cooperation between Chambers of Commerce, a role that has been acknowledged by leading European and international institutions. It also occupies a privileged position in terms of representing the private sector in the region.<ref>[http://www.ascame.org/representation ASCAME Representation and Nature]</ref>
==International Cooperation==
The latest cooperation agreements are:
• ASCAME - UfM <ref>[http://ufmsecretariat.org/ufm-and-ascame-team-up-to-accelerate-economic-integration-in-the-mediterranean]</ref>
• ASCAME - Euro-Region Mediterranean Pyrenees
• ASCAME - Eurochambres- CPCCAF <ref>[http://news.marweb.com/tunisia/economics/business/european-african-mediterranean-commerce-industry-tunis-declarati.html European, African and Mediterranean Chambers of commerce and industry adopt "Tunis Declaration"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120324074342/http://news.marweb.com/tunisia/economics/business/european-african-mediterranean-commerce-industry-tunis-declarati.html |date=March 24, 2012 }}</ref>
• ASCAME - AFAEMME <ref>[http://www.afaemme.org/ascame.php AFAEMME signs cooperation agreement with ASCAME] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120328075902/http://www.afaemme.org/ascame.php |date=March 28, 2012 }}</ref>
• ASCAME - EIA
• ASCAME - AIC FORUM <ref>[http://www.forumaic.org/layout/informazioni/allegati/Newsletter12009.pdf AIC FORUM and ASCAME sign Memorandum of Understanding]</ref>
• ASCAME - [[IEMed]]
• ASCAME - [[European Investment Bank|EIB]]
• ASCAME - US Chamber
• ASCAME - FERRMED <ref>[http://www.interempresas.net/Transporte/Articulos/41333-Ascame-Ferrmed-firman-un-acuerdo-de-colaboracion.html ASCAME and FERRMED sign a collaboration agreement]</ref>

'''''Accounting Today''''' is a [[trade magazine]] servicing the [[public accounting]] profession in the [[United States]]. Started in 1987, it grew to a circulation of more than 30,000. The [[parent company]] of ''Accounting Today'' is [[SourceMedia]]. With over 400 employees<ref>http://www.accountanttoday.com.my/index.php?ws=career{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Source Media is the publisher of more than 30 [[periodical]] brands including several major financial magazines. SourceMedia publications include ''[[American Banker]]'', ''[[The Bond Buyer]]'', ''Employee Benefit News'', and ''Financial Planning''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://solutions.sourcemedia.com/our_audience.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-05-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100128025054/http://solutions.sourcemedia.com/our_audience.html |archivedate=2010-01-28 }}</ref>
''Accounting Today'' is one of SourceMedia's [[Core product|flagship products]], and in 2009 the company merged the brand with two of their other existing accounting titles, ''Accounting Technology'' and ''Practical Accountant''. This increased the brand's print [[Circulation (journal)|circulation]] to its current level, as of October 2012, of about 60,000.<ref>http://www03.entrepreneur.com/tradejournals/article/203026182.html{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
''Accounting Today's'' [[website]] is at accountingtoday.com. Accounting Today's web site tracks related accounting news and hosts the Accounting Today [[blog]], ''Accounting Tomorrow''.

'''Armin Baniaz Pahamin''' is a Malaysian entrepreneur who rose to prominence when he was elected the Deputy President of the [[Proton (car)]] Edar Dealers Association [[Malaysia]] (PEDA) when the Proton car dealers were troubled with foreign companies take-over attempt and the conflict between two largest Proton car distributors in Malaysia, [[EON Berhad]] and Proton Edar Sdn Bhd. He was elected the 3rd President of the Proton dealers in 2010.
He was featured as a successful young millionaire by Malaysia Personal MONEY, the Edge financial magazine<ref>[http://www.theedgemalaysia.com/about-us.html The Edge Malaysia Financial Media Group] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090520055757/http://www.theedgemalaysia.com/about-us.html |date=20 May 2009 }}</ref><ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20090311231621/http://202.56.90.21/ads/A4_web_TEM%26PM_2009.pdf Personal Money, The Edge Financial Magazine, Issue #75 November 2007]</ref> on managing finances in 2007. Prior to his business endeavour, Armin was with the Commerce International Merchant Bankers Berhad [[CIMB]] in [[corporate finance]]. Armin was the Executive chairman for Jackspeed<ref>[http://www.airasia.com/storage/bo/aaportal.model.ContentFileUpload/3361b27a-c0a8c85d-177e6b40-31ed7f10/name/AirAsia_Prospectus_Local_English.pdf Airasia Prospectus pg 170] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090711025250/http://www.airasia.com/storage/bo/aaportal.model.ContentFileUpload/3361b27a-c0a8c85d-177e6b40-31ed7f10/name/AirAsia_Prospectus_Local_English.pdf |date=11 July 2009 }}</ref> Industries (M) Sdn Bhd, a subsidiary of Jackspeed Corporation Ltd, a company listed on the main board of [[Singapore stock exchange]].
Armin is as of 2015, the managing director of Fasfik (M) Sdn Bhd,<ref>[http://www.fasfik.com/ Fasfik Malaysia] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090504213019/http://www.fasfik.com/ |date=4 May 2009 }}</ref> the first Malaysian to established the largest chain of independent automotive service centre in Malaysia.<ref>[http://web6.bernama.com/cars/?type=read&id=285640 Fasfik eyes 30 pct auto service market share; [[Bernama]] news, 18 September 2007]</ref><ref>[http://web6.bernama.com/cars/?type=read&id=276279 Fasfik, the largest independent auto service chain in Malaysia [[Bernama]] news, 30 July 2007]</ref> He also sits on the board of other [[private limited companies]].
Armin was diagnosed with a Chronic Myeloid [[Leukaemia]] when he was 15 years old and underwent a [[bone marrow transplant]] a year later at the [[Hammersmith Hospital]], London in 1990. Despite the leukaemia, Armin expedited his study after the bone marrow transplant and graduated when he was barely 20 years old. Armin is also an [[Ironman Triathlon]] 2005 finisher,<ref>[http://www.3athlon.de/community/showthread.php?t=4696&page=8 Ironman Malaysia Findett Statt]</ref> Powerman Malaysia<ref>[http://www.powerman.com.my/v09/ Powerman Malaysia Dualthon] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090517215024/http://www.powerman.com.my/v09/ |date=17 May 2009 }}</ref> Dualthon 2004 finisher<ref>[http://www.powerman.com.my/pman%20results/2004/Overall%20Men.pdf Powerman Dualthon Malaysia Finisher Result pg 6] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722231907/http://www.powerman.com.my/pman%20results/2004/Overall%20Men.pdf |date=22 July 2011 }}</ref> and [[Kuala Lumpur]] International [[marathon]] 2008 finisher.<ref>[http://www.atletismoenmexico.com/2008/M08/Re42kKuala08.pdf Kuala Lumpur International Marathon race result pg. 6]</ref> He celebrated his 20 years leukaemia anniversary in 2009.
Armin graduated with a Bachelor of Science (Honours) in Economics from the [[University of Buckingham]], United Kingdom in 1995.
His father, Datuk Pahamin A Rajab<ref>[http://www.airasia.com/storage/bo/aaportal.model.ContentFileUpload/3361b27a-c0a8c85d-177e6b40-31ed7f10/name/AirAsia_Prospectus_Local_English.pdf Airasia Prospectus Pg. 141] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090711025250/http://www.airasia.com/storage/bo/aaportal.model.ContentFileUpload/3361b27a-c0a8c85d-177e6b40-31ed7f10/name/AirAsia_Prospectus_Local_English.pdf |date=11 July 2009 }}</ref> was the former founding chairman [[Airasia]] Berhad and the [[Secretary-General]] of the [[Malaysia]] Ministry of Domestic Trade and Consumer Affair.

{{Infobox person | name = August Getty | image = | caption = | birth_name = August Williams{{cite web|url=http://www.lamag.com/theseen/get-to-know-the-getty-family-tree/|title=Get to Know the Getty Family Tree Los Angeles Magazine|date=1 April 2015|website=Lamag.com|accessdate=18 July 2018}} | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1994|6|23}} | birth_place = | parents = [[Ariadne Getty]] (mother)
Justin Williams (father) | relatives = [[Getty family]] | other_names = | residence = [[Los Angeles]], [[California]],
[[United States]] | education = | alma_mater = | occupation = fashion designer | years_active = 2014 - present }} '''August Williams''', more commonly known as '''August Getty''', (born June 23, 1994) is an American fashion designer and founder of the fashion brand ''August Getty Atelier''. == Early life and family == Getty is the son of [[Ariadne Getty]],{{cite web|url=https://www.glaad.org/about/board/ariadnegetty|title=Ariadne Getty (Los Angeles, CA) (October 2016 - Present)|date=12 October 2016|website=Glaad.org|accessdate=18 July 2018}} a member of the [[Getty family]], and Justin Williams. He is the grandson of [[John Paul Getty Jr.|Sir John Paul Getty, Jr.]] and the great-grandson of actress [[Ann Rork Light]] and [[J. Paul Getty|Jean Paul Getty]], the founder of [[Getty Oil]].{{cite web|url=https://www.visionaryartistrymag.com/2016/02/august-getty-the-heir-apparel/|title=August Getty: The Heir Apparel - Visionary Artistry Magazine|date=8 February 2016|website=Visionaryartistrymag.com|accessdate=18 July 2018}} He has a sister, [[Nats Getty|Natalia]]. Getty is of Italian and English heritage.{{cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/brad-hammer/august-getty-the-next-gen_b_5909482.html|title=August Getty: The Next Generation of Fashion|first=Brad|last=Hammer|date=1 October 2014|website=Huffingtonpost.com|accessdate=18 July 2018}} He was home schooled from the age of sixteen until the end of high school.{{cite web|url=https://www.wmagazine.com/story/august-getty-fashion-designer|title=August Start|first=Lee|last=Carter|website=Wmagazine.com|accessdate=18 July 2018}} == Career == As a teenager Getty was influenced by designers [[Alexander McQueen]], [[Versace]], [[Vivienne Westwood]] and [[Stella McCartney]]. He has also stated that he has a strong connection to [[Yves Saint Laurent (designer)|Yves Saint Laurent]]{{cite web|url=https://www.out.com/out-exclusives/out100-2014/2014/11/11/out100-fashion-designer-august-getty|title=OUT100: Fashion Designer August Getty|date=11 November 2014|website=Out.com|accessdate=18 July 2018}} In 2014 Getty premiered his 2015 Spring/Summer collection at the [[Mercedes-Benz]] fashion show in New York City during [[New York Fashion Week]]. The collection was based on childhood fantasies Getty had about European heiresses with secret lives, statues in his family's art collection, and his family's botanical gardens.{{cite web|url=http://mbfashionweek.com/designers/august-getty|title=Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week|website=Mbfashionweek.com|accessdate=18 July 2018}} In November 2015 Getty collaborated with [[David LaChappelle]] for his 2016 Spring/Summer collection called ''Thread of Man''. His collection's debut was an art installation at [[Universal Studios]] instead of a traditional fashion show. The installation involved art scenes depicting a car accident, an altar to [[Our Lady of Guadalupe]], and footage of [[Fox News]] and U.S. President [[Donald Trump]] underneath a neon sign spelling out ''Hell''.{{cite web|url=https://fashionista.com/2015/11/august-getty-david-lachapelle-spring-2016|title=David LaChapelle and August Getty Created a Dystopian Model Wasteland at Universal Studios|website=Fasionista.com|accessdate=18 July 2018}} His 2016 Autumn/Winter line was featured in ''[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.vogue.co.uk/shows/autumn-winter-2016-ready-to-wear/august-getty|title=August Getty Autumn/Winter 2016 Ready-To-Wear show report|website=Vogue.co.uk|accessdate=18 July 2018}} Getty's Spring 2018 collection made its debut at the [[Four Seasons Hotels and Resorts|Four Seasons Hotel]] in [[Milan]].{{cite web|url=http://wwd.com/runway/spring-ready-to-wear-2018/milan/august-getty/review/|title=August Getty RTW Spring 2018|first=Mayte|last=Allende|date=25 September 2017|website=Wwd.com|accessdate=18 July 2018}} In March 2018 Getty opened a boutique in [[Beverly Hills]],{{cite web|url=https://www.apparelnews.net/news/2017/dec/28/getty-heir-takes-retail-rodeo-drive/|title=Getty Heir Takes Retail to Rodeo Drive|website=Apparelnews.net|accessdate=18 July 2018}} the first for ''August Getty Atelier''.{{cite web|url=https://augustgetty.com|title=August Getty Atelier – Official Website of Los Angeles Luxury Designer August Getty|website=Augustgetty.com|accessdate=18 July 2018}} He has dressed celebrities including [[Gigi Gorgeous]], [[Kim Kardashian]], [[Paris Hilton]], [[Miley Cyrus]], [[Katy Perry]], [[Bebe Rexha]], and [[Rachel McAdams]].{{cite web|url=https://www.vogue.com.au/culture/red-carpet/meet-august-getty-the-22-yearold-who-made-rachel-mcadams-oscars-gown/news-story/91145f3b774b6bdbd8f519b4573231b7?|title=Meet August Getty, the 22 year-old who made Rachel McAdams' Oscars gown - {{short description|International minimum standard for entry level recreational scuba diver certification}} '''Autonomous diver''' describes the minimum requirements for basic training and certification for [[Recreational diving|recreational scuba divers]] in international standard ISO 24801-2 <ref name=" ISO24801-2">{{cite web |url=https://www.iso.org/obp/ui/#iso:std:iso:24801:-2:ed-2:v1:en|title=Recreational diving services — Requirements for the training of recreational scuba divers — Part 2: Level 2 — Autonomous diver (ISO 24801-2) |publisher=[[International Standards Organisation|ISO]] |access-date=2015-04-29}}</ref> and the equivalent European Standard EN 14153-2. Various organizations offer training that meets the requirements of the Autonomous Diver standard. A certification which corresponds to Autonomous Diver allows for independent diving with a [[Buddy diving|dive buddy]] in [[Open water diving|open water]]. Most training organizations do not recommend exceeding a depth of 18 or 20 meters at this level of certification. After completion this certification the training can be extended to a dive leader to ISO 24801-3 or an intermediate not defined by international standards.
[[File:Scuba_education_levels.svg|thumb|upright=2.2|Scuba diving education levels as used by ISO, PADI, CMAS, SSI and NAUI]] Before initial diver training and thereafter at regular intervals, a diver should undergo a [[fitness to dive]] examination by a diving doctor. In some countries, such an examination is required by law and it is a prerequisite for any training in many diving schools. A diving certification which corresponds to Autonomous Diver and a medical certificate may be required for renting diving equipment and taking part in organised dives. In some countries (e.g. Australia) the law requires every diver to prove basic certification before unsupervised diving activity.<ref name="ozzy">{{cite web | url=http://www.royallifesaving.com.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0013/4045/Scuba_Diving_Report_Final_2008.pdf | title=Recreational Scuba Diving & Snorkelling Safety in Australia - An identification, summary and analysis of policies, legislation and standards relevant to recreational scuba diving and snorkelling | publisher=[[Divers Alert Network|DAN]] Asia, Pacific Head Office, Ashburton ''and'' Royal Life Saving Society Australia (RLSSA) | date=2008 | access-date=2014-03-04 | format=PDF}}</ref>
Some diver training organizations offer an intermediate [[Supervised diver]] certification which corresponds to ISO 24801-1, which usually only splits the contents of the Autonomous Diver training over two courses and does not qualify the holder to take part in independent dives.
==Scope of the standard== International standard ISO 24801-2 includes:<ref name=" ISO24801-2" /> *Prerequisites for training, including age and health requirements, *Required theoretical knowledge regarding scuba and basic diving equipment, the basic physics of diving, decompression management and dive planning, medical and psychological problems related to diving, the diving environment and the use of nitrox breathing gases, *Required scuba skills in confined and open water, *Practical training parameters, *Evaluation of knowledge and practical skills.
==Training according to ISO 24801-2== Every year around 1.7 million people are trained according to ISO 24801.<ref name="Statistics">945 000 annual certification by PADI {{cite web | url=http://www.padi.com/scuba/uploadedFiles/Scuba_--Do_not_use_this_folder_at_al/About_PADI/PADI_Statistics/2012%20WW%20Statistics.pdf | title=Worldwide Corporate Statistics 2013 - Data for 2007-2012 | publisher=PADI| date=February 2013 | access-date=2013-11-01| format=PDF|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131102033307/http://www.padi.com/scuba/uploadedFiles/Scuba_--Do_not_use_this_folder_at_al/About_PADI/PADI_Statistics/2012%20WW%20Statistics.pdf | archive-date=2013-11-02 }} with market share of 56%, {{cite web | url=http://www.divebuddy.com/blog/11295/2013-market-share-scuba-certification-agencies-padi-naui-ssi/ | title=2013 Market Share of Scuba Certification Agencies (PADI, NAUI, SSI) | publisher=DiveBuddy.com | date=2013-07-25 |author=Greg | access-date=2013-11-01}} gives a total of about 1.7 million.</ref> Despite the standardization, the dive courses of individual diving organizations differ considerably in their content, expansion and philosophy. However, the minimum requirements defined in the ISO standard guarantee that a diver can easily convert between training organizations.
The following certifications meet the requirements for Autonomous Diver:
=== CMAS * === [[File:CMAS-Ausbildung.svg|thumb|upright=1.8|The CMAS certification sustem]] The [[CMAS* SCUBA Diver|CMAS *]] (one-star) training goes beyond the requirements defined by the Autonomous Diver standard. CMAS requires the theory test before diving in open water. 6 theory lessons,<ref name="CMAS1">{{cite web | url=http://www.idiving.de/de/tauchen-diving-book/tauchen-lernen-cmas-1stern | title= Tauchen lernen| work=CMAS * (1Stern) | publisher=Dortmund idiving.de | access-date=2014-02-24 |language=de}}</ref> which build the basic understanding of the learner diver and, after the successful completion of a theory test, at least 6 swimming pool or confined water training sessions, and 5 open water training and assessment dives. The course includes breathhold exercises. After successfully completing the course, training can continue with specialisation courses or the CMAS ** (two star). CMAS recommends maximum depth of 20 meters for one-star divers. For divers aged between 8 and 14 years, a maximum depth of 5 meters is recommended.
The CMAS * course can be started without prior knowledge of diving. Persons who wish to attend a CMAS * course must be at least 14 years old, and in normal physical health and fitness.
The basic training standards of the individual CMAS member organizations may differ from the training specified by CMAS.
===NAUI Scuba Diver=== The NAUI Scuba Diver course (SD) is a basic diving certification training which corresponds to the standardized Autonomous Diver.<ref name="NAUI-ISO">{{cite web |url=http://www.easydivers.ch/ueber_uns/zertifikat_iso_naui.pdf |title=Certificate | work=Nr. EUF - CB 2007 004 |publisher=European Underwater Federation (EUF) |access-date=2013-12-02 |language=de }}</ref> The training includes 2 breath-hold and 4 scuba dives. NAUI recommends SD divers to dive to a maximum depth not exceeding 18 meters. After successful completion, the training can be continued with specialty certification or the Advanced Scuba Diver course. The NAUI SD course can be started without previous knowledge of diving. Normal physical health and fitness are required. Persons who wish to attend an SD course must be at least 15 years old. NAUI Junior Scuba Diver training can be attended at the age of 12 years.<ref name="NAUI-SD">{{cite web | url=http://www.northernatlanticdive.com/NAUI_courses/OW-course_rev1.pdf | title=NAUI Scuba Diver (Open Water) | publisher=Northern Atlantic Dive Expeditions, Inc. and R/V Gauntlet | date=2008-03-01 | access-date=2014-02-24 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130323071139/http://www.northernatlanticdive.com/NAUI_courses/OW-course_rev1.pdf | archive-date=2013-03-23 | dead-url=yes | df= }}</ref> These children's diving courses differ only in a child-oriented mediation of the same contents.
===PADI Open Water Diver=== [[File:PADI-Ausbildungssystem.svg|thumb|upright=2.4|Overview of the PADI training system]] The [[Professional Association of Diving Instructors|PADI]] [[Open Water Diver]] Course (OWD) is an entry level diver training programme to the ISO standards for Autonomous Diver. PADI allows OWD divers to dive to a depth of 18 meters. After successful completion, training can be continued with specialties or the Advanced Open Water Diver course.
The course consists of five theory lessons, five swimming pool dives and at least four dives in open water on scuba. They also recommend an optional snorkeling dive and / or "adventure dive". PADI follows the "dive today" concept. Therefore, after a theory lesson, the dives are usually held on the same day. The pool dives - which can also be done at calm, current-free, shallow places in open water, provide for learning the basic and emergency techniques. These include entering the water, breathing under water from the scuba regulator, using the fins, basic [[Scuba skills#Buoyancy control|buoyancy control]], clearing the mask, recovery of the demand valve and [[emergency ascent]].<ref name="OWD-Exler" /> In the open water dives, the same exercises are repeated in deeper water. There are also techniques for managing [[cramping]], open water [[Ascending and descending (diving)|descent and ascent]], [[buddy breathing]] and [[diver navigation]].<ref name="OWD-Exler">{{cite web | url=http://www.exler.de/owde.htm | title=PADI Open Water Diver|access-date=2017-06-12}}</ref>
OWD is an entry-level course. Normal physical health and fitness are required. Persons who wish to attend a PADI OWD course must be at least 15 years old, but a PADI Junior OWD course (JOWD) can be attended at the age of 10 years. These children's dive courses differ only in a child-oriented mediation of the same contents.
===SSI Open Water Diver=== [[File:SSI-education system.svg|thumb|upright=1.8|Overview of the SSI training system]] The [[Scuba Schools International]] (SSI) Open Water Diver Course (OWD) is a basic dive certification equivalent to the standard Autonomous Diver. The training includes at least 4 open water dives, which can only be carried out after the successful completion of the theoretical training. SSI allows OWD divers to dive to a maximum depth of 18 meters.<ref name="SSI-Standards">{{cite web | url=http://www.divessi.com/d/SSI%20Global%20Training%20Standards/2014%20Global%20Training%20Standards%20GERMAN%20(Version%20v102013).ssp | title=2014 Training & Dive Center Standards | work=Scuba Schools International / v102813 | publisher=Concept Systems International GmbH | page=REC-10 | date=2013-10-28 | access-date=2014-02-25 }}{{Dead link|date=October 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> After successful completion, training can be continued with specialties or the Advanced Adventurer Course. The SSI OWD is an entry level course. Normal physical health and fitness are required and an SSI Medical Statement must be provided. The learner must be able to swim 180 meters without an aid. Persons who wish to attend an OWD course must be at least 15 years old. An SSI Junior OWD training can be completed at the age of 10 years. [11] These children's dive courses differ only in a child-oriented mediation of the same contents.
===Other training agencies=== In addition to the above, the following certifications comply with the Autonomous Diver standard ISO 24801-2:<ref name="Certified">{{cite web |url=https://certificates.austrian-standards.at/EUF_training_systems?5 |title=EUF Certified Training Systems/Training Organisations |publisher=European Underwater Federation (EUF) |access-date=2017-04-21}}</ref>

{{other uses|Blue ribbon (disambiguation)|Blue Riband (disambiguation)}} [[File:Mauretania - Full speed ahead.jpg|thumb|300px|Cunard's ''Mauretania'' during sea trials. Longer than any other contender, she held the Blue Riband for 20 years, from 1909 to 1929.]]
The '''Blue Riband''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|r|ɪ|b|ə|n|d}}) is an unofficial accolade given to the [[Passenger ship|passenger liner]] crossing the Atlantic Ocean in regular service with the record highest speed. The term was borrowed from [[horse racing]] and was not widely used until after 1910.<ref name=kludas>{{cite book | last=Kludas | first=Arnold | title=Record breakers of the North Atlantic, Blue Riband Liners 1838–1952 | location=London | publisher=Chatham | year=2000 | isbn=1-86176-141-4}}</ref><ref name=fox>{{cite book | last=Fox | first=Stephen | title=Transatlantic: Samuel Cunard, Isambard Brunel and the Great Atlantic Steamships | location=New York | publisher=HarperCollins| year=2003| isbn=0-06-019595-9}}</ref> Traditionally, the record is based on [[Velocity|average speed]] rather than passage time because ships follow different routes.<ref name=gibbs>{{cite book | last=Gibbs | first=Charles Robert Vernon | title=Passenger Liners of the Western Ocean: A Record of Atlantic Steam and Motor Passenger Vessels from 1838 to the Present Day | location=London | publisher=Staples Press | year=1957 | oclc=225962096}}</ref> Also, eastbound and westbound speed records are reckoned separately, as the more difficult westbound record voyage, against the [[Gulf Stream]] and the prevailing weather systems, typically results in lower average speeds.
Of the 35 Atlantic liners to hold the Blue Riband, 25 were British, followed by five German, three American, as well as one each from Italy and France. Thirteen were [[Cunard Line|Cunarders]] (plus [[RMS Queen Mary|''Queen Mary'']] of Cunard White Star), 5 by [[White Star Line|White Star]], with 4 owned by [[Norddeutscher Lloyd]], 2 by [[Collins Line|Collins]], 2 by [[Inman Line|Inman]] and 2 by [[Guion Line|Guion]], and one each by [[British and American Steam Navigation Company|British American]], [[Great Western Steamship Company|Great Western]], [[Hamburg America Line|Hamburg-America]], the [[Italian Line]], [[Compagnie Générale Transatlantique]] and finally the [[United States Lines]].<ref name=kludas /> The record set by ''[[SS United States|United States]]'' in 1952 remains unbroken by any passenger liner. The next longest period through which the Blue Riband was retained was 19 years, held from 1909 to 1929 by ''Mauretania''. The shortest period was 6 weeks, by ''Bremen'' from July to August 1933. [[File:SS United States on maiden voyage from Southampton.jpg|right|thumb|300px|[[SS United States|SS ''United States'']], last winner of the Blue Riband.]] Many of these ships were built with substantial government subsidies and were designed with military considerations in mind.<ref name=gibbs /> [[Winston Churchill]] estimated that the two Cunard Queens helped shorten the Second World War by a year.<ref name=graham /> The last Atlantic liner to hold the Blue Riband, the [[SS United States|SS ''United States'']], was designed for her potential use as a troopship as well as her service as a commercial passenger liner.<ref name=gibbs />
There was no formal award until 1935, when [[Harold Hales|Harold K. Hales]] donated the [[Hales Trophy]]; though the rules for the Hales Trophy were different from the traditional rules for the Blue Riband (for example, the [[Hales Trophy]] was originally only awarded for westbound records<ref name="Kludas p17">Kludas p17</ref>) and changed several times thereafter. It was awarded to just three Blue Riband holders during the express liner era. The trophy continues to be awarded, though many people believe the ''United States'' remains as the holder of the Blue Riband because no subsequent record breaker was in Atlantic passenger service.<ref name=kludas />
The [[Ocean rowing|Ocean Rowing]] Society inspired by The Blue Riband concept created Blue Riband Trophy of Ocean Rowing awarded to the fastest crew to cross the Atlantic Ocean in an unsupported row boat. Presently it is the most sought after trophy of ocean rowing.<ref name="oceanrowing.com">{{Cite web|url=http://www.oceanrowing.com/statistics/record_standard.htm|title=ocean rowing world records blue riband trophy|website=www.oceanrowing.com|access-date=2016-11-08}}</ref>
==Background== The first well-documented crossing of the North Atlantic, though [[List of crossings of the Atlantic Ocean|not the earliest]], was that of [[John Cabot]]'s ship [[Matthew (ship)|''Matthew'']] in the summer of 1497. ''Matthew'' crossed from [[Bristol]] to [[Newfoundland (island)|Newfoundland]] in 35 days, returning the following month in just 17 days.<ref>Peter Firstbrook (1997) ''The Voyage of the Matthew'' p118 BBC Books {{ISBN|0 563 38764 5}}</ref> Over the next three centuries countless vessels (merchant ships and warships, fast and slow, in peace and war) crossed back and forth over the North Atlantic, all subject to the vagaries of wind and weather. They arrived at port when they could, dependent on the wind, and left when they were loaded, frequently visiting other ports to complete their cargo. During this period eastbound passages of 30 and 45 days were not uncommon, while westward passages of 65 to 90 days excited no attention. It was the advent of the steam ship, with its independence from wind power, which offered the possibility of regular, scheduled Atlantic crossings, in periods of two to three weeks, that opened a new era of transatlantic travel and competition.<ref>Kludas p33</ref>
==History== The term “Blue Riband of the Atlantic” did not come into use until the 1890s, and the history of the trans-Atlantic competition, which was compiled retrospectively, was regarded as starting with the crossings by the steamships [[SS Sirius (1837)|''Sirius'']] and [[SS Great Western|''Great Western'']] in 1838. Although not the first steamships to cross the Atlantic ([[SS Savannah|''Savannah'']] had crossed in 1819, and [[SS Royal William|''Royal William'']] in 1831) nor the fastest to make the crossing (the [[Packet boat|packet]] sailing ship ''Columbia'' crossed west to east in 15 days 23 hours in 1830,<ref>Carl Cutler (1984) ''Greyhounds of the Sea|'' US Naval Institute {{ISBN|978-0850597288}}</ref> and crossings by sail packets of 16 and 17 days were not unheard of) the ''Sirius'' and ''Great Western'' were the first steamships offering a regular, scheduled trans-Atlantic service; and crucially, they were involved in a race.<ref>Kludas p36-37</ref> Cunard refused officially to recognise the title because racing vessels was not in line with the company's safety policy.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Great Transatlantic Liners|url=http://www.liverpoolmuseums.org.uk/maritime/archive/rtf/Ships-Great%20Transatlantic%20Liners%2C%20The%20no8.rtf|website=Maritime Archives|publisher=Merseyside Maritime Museum|accessdate=14 November 2017}}</ref>
===Paddlers (1838–72)===
[[File:SS Sirius (1837).jpg|thumb|''Sirius'' is considered the first Atlantic record-holder for her 1838 voyage to New York at {{convert|8.03|kn|km/h}}.]] [[File:Great Western maiden voyage.jpg|thumb|In 1843, ''Great Western'' recorded a record-breaking voyage of {{convert|10.03|kn|km/h}}.]] The idea of building a line of transatlantic steamships was mooted in 1832 by Junius Smith, American lawyer turned London merchant. The idea came to him during an Atlantic crossing which took 57 days, a not unusual occurrence,<ref>Kludas p36</ref> and it was published in the ''American Rail Road Journal''.<ref name=pond>{{cite book | last = Pond | first = Edgar LeRoy | coauthors = | title = Janius Smith | location = | publisher=| year = 1927 | oclc = | page = }}</ref> After receiving no support for several years, his plan gained credibility when Scottish shipbuilder, [[Macgregor Laird]] became an investor.<ref name=fox /> Smith, who is often considered the ''Father of the Atlantic Liner'', formed the [[British and American Steam Navigation Company]] to operate a London-New York service. About the same time, the question of Atlantic steamships was discussed at an 1835 director's meeting of the newly formed Great Western Railway when the line’s chief engineer, [[Isambard Kingdom Brunel]] supposedly joked that the line could be made longer by building a steamship to run between Bristol and New York. The necessary investors were recruited by Brunel's friend, Thomas Guppy, a Bristol engineer and businessman.<ref name=heritage>{{cite book | last = American Heritage | first = | title = The Annihilation of Time and Space | location = | publisher=| year = 1991 | oclc = | pages = }}</ref> The next year, the [[Great Western Steamship Company]] was established, even though the rail line was still years from completion.<ref name=corlett>{{cite book | last = Corlett | first = Ewan | title = The Iron Ship: the Story of Brunel's ss Great Britain | location = | publisher=Conway | year = 1975 | oclc = | pages = }}</ref>
By spring 1838, Brunel’s {{SS|Great Western||2}} was ready for sea, but Smith’s first ship was still without engines. When Great Western scheduled its initial sailing, Laird suggested that British and American charter the Irish Sea steamer {{SS|Sirius|1837|2}} from the St. George Steam Packet Company for two voyages to beat Great Western.<ref name=heritage /> While the ''Sirius'' left [[Cork (city)|Cork]], Ireland four days before ''Great Western'' departed [[Avonmouth]], ''Great Western'' still came within a day of overtaking ''Sirius'' to New York.<ref name=gibbs /> To complete the voyage, ''Sirius'' was forced to burn spars when coal ran low.<ref name=heritage /> With her westbound crossing at 8.03 [[Knots (speed)|knots]] (14.87 [[km/h]]), ''Sirius'' is often considered the first record holder even though the notion would not be used for several generations.<ref name=kludas /> ''Great Western'' herself became the prototype for all successful wooden paddlers and made a record-breaking voyage at {{convert|10.03|kn|km/h}} as late as 1843.<ref name=gibbs />
[[File:RMS Europa.jpg|thumb|right|''Europa'' of 1848 set the record with a voyage of {{convert|11.79|kn|km/h}}. This is one of the earliest known photos of an Atlantic steamship.]] The [[Cunard Line]] started its Liverpool-Halifax-Boston service in 1840 with the four ships that were slightly reduced versions of ''Great Western'' with about the same speed. Ultimately Cunard built nine additional wood paddlers. By 1846, Cunard was the only original steamship line that survived, largely because of its subsidy from the British [[Admiralty]] to carry the mails<ref name=gibbs /> and its emphasis on safety.<ref name=graham>{{cite book | last = Maxtone-Graham | first = John | title = The Only Way To Cross | location = | publisher=Collier | year = 1972 | oclc = | pages = }}</ref> Until 1850, the record passed between various Cunarders, finally reaching {{convert|12.25|kn|km/h}} for an 8-day Liverpool-Halifax crossing by ''Asia''.<ref name=kludas /> Record voyages during this period were often the result of using sails to gain extra speed from a following gale.<ref name=gibbs />
Cunard's first serious competition for the record came from the American-owned [[Collins Line]].<ref name=gibbs /> The American Government supplied Collins with a substantial subsidy to operate four wooden paddlers that were superior to Cunard's best.<ref name=fry>{{cite book | last = Fry | first = Henry | title = The History of North Atlantic Steam Navigation with Some Account of Early Ships and Shipowners| location = London | publisher=Sampson, Low & Marston | year = 1896 | oclc = 271397492 | page = }}</ref> In its first year, 1850, the {{SS|Pacific|1849|2}} set the record at {{convert|12.46|kn|km/h}} on a 10-day run from Liverpool to New York. Unfortunately, Collins suffered a setback when its {{SS|Arctic||2}} foundered with heavy loss of life.<ref name=gibbs /> The next year, Cunard put further pressure on Collins by commissioning its first iron-hulled paddler, the [[RMS Persia|''Persia'']], which set a new record with a 9-day, 16-hour Liverpool-New York voyage at {{convert|13.11|kn|km/h}}.<ref name=kludas /> During the [[Crimean War]], Cunard supplied eleven of its ships for war service and suspended all routes except the Liverpool-Halifax-Boston service.<ref name=fry /> While the Collins' fortunes improved because of the lack of competition during the war, Collins collapsed in 1858 after the loss of two additional steamers.<ref name=gibbs /> Cunard emerged as the leading carrier of first class passengers and in 1862 commissioned the [[RMS Scotia|''Scotia'']], the last paddle steamer to set a record with a Queenstown-New York voyage at {{convert|14.46|kn|km/h}}. ''Scotia'' was the final significant paddler ordered for the Atlantic because under the terms of Cunard's mail contract with the Admiralty, it was still required to supply paddle steamers when needed for military service.<ref name=kludas />
===Single screw steamers (1872–89)=== [[File:Adriatic (1871).jpg|thumb|White Star's ''Adriatic'' by George Parker Greenwood. She was the first successful screw liner with an 1872 run at {{convert|14.65|kn|km/h}}]] [[File:RMS Etruria.jpg|thumb|Cunard's ''Etruria'' of 1885, averaged {{convert|19.56|kn|km/h}} on a record-breaking 1888 crossing]]
In 1845, Brunel’s {{SS|Great Britain||2}} became the first iron-hulled screw liner on the Atlantic. Starting in 1850, the [[Inman Line]] built numerous reduced versions for the [[steerage (deck)|steerage]] trade. In 1866, Inman started to commission single screw express liners that were the equal of ''Scotia''.<ref name=gibbs /> The Admiralty allowed Cunard to order its first screw express liner, the ''Russia''.<ref name=fry /> In 1871 both companies faced a new rival when the [[White Star Line]] commissioned [[RMS Oceanic (1870)|''Oceanic'']] and her five sisters. The following year, White Star’s ''Adriatic'' finally surpassed ''Scotia'' with a voyage at {{convert|14.65|kn|km/h}}.<ref name=kludas /> The new White Star record breakers were especially economical because of their use of compound engines, but their high ratio of length to beam (10:1 compared to the previous norm of 8:1) increased vibration. To counter this, White Star placed the dining saloon midships and made their ships more luxurious. Inman rebuilt its express fleet to the new standard, but Cunard lagged behind both of its rivals.<ref name=gibbs /> In 1875, Inman’s new [[SS City of Berlin|''City of Berlin'']] averaged {{convert|15.21|kn|km/h}} on its record-breaking voyage.<ref name=kludas />
During the five-year [[Panic of 1873|shipping depression]] that began in 1873, William Pearce, the controlling partner of the [[Fairfield Shipbuilding|John Elder shipyard]], became convinced that a crack steamer that carried only passengers and light freight could be profitable because she would attract more passengers and spend less time in port.<ref name=fox /> He proposed a ship that crammed the most powerful machinery possible into the hull, sacrificing everything to speed.<ref name=gibbs /> When Cunard rejected his proposal, Pearce offered his idea to the [[Guion Line]], a firm primarily engaged in the steerage trade. The first ship Pearce built for Guion, the [[SS Arizona|''Arizona'']] was described as a "souped up transatlantic hot rod" by one nautical historian.<ref name=fox /> While she only won the eastbound record,<ref name=fry /> two years later, Guion took delivery of the even faster ''Alaska'' that set the record at {{convert|16.07|kn|km/h}}.<ref name=kludas /> To continue the program, Pearce offered Guion favourable terms on a third unit, the [[SS Oregon (1883)|''Oregon'']], which raised the record to {{convert|18.56|kn|km/h}} in 1884.<ref name=kludas /> These ships were uncomfortable and their excessive coal consumption made them uneconomic.<ref name=gibbs /> However, for a while they were popular with American clients because of their American ownership.<ref name=fry />
After being out of the contest for a decade, Cunard finally started to rebuild. In 1884, Cunard purchased ''Oregon'' from the Guion line when that firm defaulted on payments to the shipyard. Later that year, Cunard commissioned the first steel-hulled record-breakers, [[RMS Umbria|''Umbria'']] and [[RMS Etruria|''Etruria'']].<ref name=fry /> ''Etruria'', the faster of the pair, raised the record to {{convert|19.56|kn|km/h}} on a 6-day, 2-hour run from Queenstown to Sandy Hook in 1888. However, ''Etruria'' and her sister represented the limit of single screw technology.<ref name=kludas />
===Double screw steamers (1889–1907)=== [[File:City of paris.jpg|thumb|Inman's ''City of Paris'' set a record of {{convert|20.01|kn|km/h}} in 1889.]] [[File:Kaiser wilhelm der grosse 01.jpg|thumb|NDL's ''Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse'' raised the record to {{convert|22.29|kn|km/h}} in 1898]] The Inman line fell on hard times after their intended record-breaker, ''City of Rome'' failed to meet expectations and was returned to her builders in 1882. Inman directors agreed to voluntary liquidation so that the largest creditor, the Philadelphia-based [[International Navigation Company]] could purchase Inman's assets.<ref name=gibbs /> The new owners provided the capital to build two outstanding record breakers, the twin screw {{SS|City of New York||2}} and the {{SS|City of Paris|1888|2}}. Starting in 1889, the later ship set the record on four occasions, including a voyage at {{convert|20.7|kn|km/h}} in 1892. White Star, which had not built an express liner since the {{SS|Germanic|1875|2}} of 1875, commissioned the record-breaker, {{SS|Teutonic|1889|2}} of 1889 and {{SS|Majestic|1890|2}} of 1890 after receiving a subsidy from the [[Admiralty]] to make the pair available as merchant cruisers in the event of hostilities. Cunard countered with two even faster ships, the [[RMS Campania|''Campania'']] and the [[RMS Lucania|''Lucania'']] of 1893.<ref name=fry /> The next year, ''Lucania'' recorded a voyage at {{convert|21.81|kn|km/h}}.<ref name=kludas /> Inman became the [[American Line]] and ordered two additional express liners from American yards, but no attempt was made to best the new Cunarders. In 1894, Guion ceased sailing as its ships were now hopelessly outdated.<ref name=gibbs />
No sooner had Cunard reestablished its supremacy than new rivals emerged. Beginning in the late 1860s, several German firms commissioned liners that were almost as fast as the British mail steamers working from Liverpool.<ref name=gibbs /> In 1889, the [[Hamburg America Line|Hamburg-America Line]] commissioned four double screw steamers capable of {{convert|18.00|kn|km/h}}. Its rival, [[Norddeutscher Lloyd]] (NDL) lagged behind until 1895 when it ordered two ships intended to take the record. In 1898, the {{SS|Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse||2}} raised the record to {{convert|22.29|kn|km/h}}, while the other liner, ''Kaiser Friedrich'' failed to achieve her contract speed and was returned to her builders. Hamburg America ordered the even more powerful {{SS|Deutschland|1900|2}} that reached {{convert|23.06|kn|km/h}} on one of her record-breaking 1900 voyages. However, Hamburg America quickly learned that these high powered double screw liners had vibration problems. ''Deutschland'' had the unpleasant nickname, "cocktail shaker" and actually lost part of her stern in 1902 because of the constant vibration.<ref name=kludas />
Rather than match the new German speedsters, White Star decided to drop out of the competition and commission the four large ''Celtic''-class luxury liners of more moderate speed. White Star realised that passengers preferred comfort even if this means spending an extra day at sea. In 1902, White Star joined the well capitalised American combine, the [[International Mercantile Marine Co.]] (IMM) that owned the American Line and others. IMM also had trade agreements with Hamburg America and Norddeutscher Lloyd. After its bad experience with the ''Deutschland'', Hamburg America also dropped out of the race and commissioned large luxury liners based on the ''Celtic''. However, NDL completed building a fleet of four additional express liners modelled on ''Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse''.<ref name=gibbs />
===Ships of state (1907–69)=== [[File:RMS Mauretania.jpg|thumb|Cunard's ''Mauretania'' held the Blue Riband from 1909 to 1929 at {{convert|26.06|kn|km/h}}]] [[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 102-11081, Schnelldamper "Bremen".jpg|thumb|NDL's ''Bremen'' finally broke ''Mauretania'''s record in 1929 by averaging {{convert|27.83|kn|km/h}}]] [[File:B-17s flyby Rex.jpg|thumb|The Italian ''Rex'' joined the Blue Riband club with a 1933 voyage of {{convert|28.92|kn|km/h}}]] [[File:SS-Normandie side01 NYC.jpg|thumb|CGT's ''Normandie'' won the Blue Riband at {{convert|30.58|kn|km/h}} in 1937.]] [[File:Rms queen mary 2008.jpg|thumb|Cunard White Star's ''Queen Mary'' regained the Blue Riband at {{convert|30.99|kn|km/h}} in 1938.]] [[File:SS United States postcard.jpg|thumb|''United States'' won the Blue Riband at {{convert|34.51|kn|km/h}} in 1952. Formally, she still holds the title.]] After 1902, only the Cunard Line and the French [[Compagnie Générale Transatlantique]] (CGT) were independent of the IMM combine. British prestige was at stake, and the Government provided Cunard with an annual subsidy of £150,000 plus a low interest loan of £2.5 million to pay for the construction of the two [[Superliner (passenger ship)|superliners]], [[RMS Lusitania|''Lusitania'']] and [[RMS Mauretania (1906)|''Mauretania'']] under the condition that they be available for conversion to armed cruisers when needed by the navy.<ref name=gibbs /> Starting in 1907, both ships won the Blue Riband and ''Mauretania’s'' 1909 record of {{convert|26.06|kn|km/h}} stood for 20 years.<ref name=kludas /> However, these ships paid a price for speed and lacked many of the amenities found in the new White Star and Hamburg American luxury liners. Both Cunard rivals ordered a trio of even bigger luxury liners, the White Star [[Olympic class ocean liner|''Olympic''-class]] capable of {{convert|21.5|kn|km/h}} and Hapag [[SS Imperator|''Imperator''-class]] capable of {{convert|22.5|kn|km/h}}. Even Cunard chose this approach when it ordered its third superliner, the [[RMS Aquitania|''Aquitania'']].<ref name=graham />
There is a persistent rumor that {{RMS|Titanic}} was attempting to win the Blue Riband and that such effort resulted in excessive speed and collision with the iceberg.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Maltin|first1=Tim|last2=Aston|first2=Eloise|title=101 things you thought you knew about the Titanic-- but didn't!|date=2011|publisher=Penguin Books|location=New York, N.Y.|isbn=978-0143119098|pages=43-47}}Chapter 18.</ref> Such a rumor is undoubtedly false, as the Titanic was built for luxury not speed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.titanic-titanic.com/titanic_myths.shtml|title=Titanic Myths|author=|date=|website=www.titanic-titanic.com|accessdate=11 April 2018}}</ref>
As a result of the war, Hamburg American and Norddeutscher Lloyd lost their premier units. In 1926, the U.S. Government awarded Norddeutscher Lloyd (NDL) $27 million in compensation for its confiscated liners. By this time, improvements in turbine technology and hull form along with the use of fuel oil instead of coal made it possible to build more civilised record breakers. Using these funds, NDL ordered two ships designed to cross the Atlantic in five days, the {{SS|Bremen|1929|2}} and {{SS|Europa|1930|2}}. However, the American government netted the award against debts owed by the German Government and Berlin was forced to directly subsidise NDL to continue the project. ''Bremen'' recorded {{convert|27.83|kn|km/h}} on her 1929 Blue Riband voyage and ''Europa'' increased the Blue Riband to {{convert|27.92|kn|km/h}} in 1933.<ref name=kludas />
In 1928, as Britain's response to the German {{SS|Bremen|1929|2}} and {{SS|Europa|1930|2}}, the [[White Star Line]] ordered a new Diesel-electric 1000-ft long ocean liner to be named [[Oceanic (unfinished ship)|''Oceanic'']] capable of 200,000 SHP. Construction started June 28, 1928. However, White Star did not have the funds to complete the liner. Oceanic's construction was put on hold until 1931 when her keel was silently scrapped. Oceanic's ahead-of-their-time engines would have been powerful enough to enable her to possibly win the Blue Riband.
In 1929, two lines from Italy each ordered a ship based on the German pair. Just as these ships were being completed, the Italian government nationalised the shipping industry, creating the [[Italian Line]]. While both superliners were successful, only the {{SS|Rex||2}} won the Blue Riband, with a 1933 voyage at {{convert|28.92|kn|km/h}}.<ref name=gibbs />
CGT also ordered a new superliner in 1929. The next year, Cunard started construction on an 80,000 ton liner that was to be the first of two record breakers fast enough to fit into a two ship weekly Southampton-New York service.<ref name=graham /> Consequently, CGT altered its plans to make its new liner even bigger.<ref name=kludas /> However, as the 1929 shipping depression intensified, construction on Cunard’s hull 534 was halted while work on the heavily subsidised French ship continued. By 1934, both Cunard and White Star lines were failing and the British Government was concerned about potential job losses. Therefore, the government agreed to give Cunard a loan of £3 million to complete hull 534 as the {{RMS|Queen Mary||2}} and an additional £5 million to build a second ship, the {{RMS|Queen Elizabeth||2}} only if Cunard merged with White Star.<ref name=graham />
CGT's {{SS|Normandie||2}} entered service in 1935 and won the Blue Riband at {{convert|29.98|kn|km/h}}. ''Queen Mary'' was commissioned the next year, and after a few break-in voyages, took the Blue Riband to {{convert|30.14|kn|km/h}}. The two liners were operated a pair and traded the Blue Riband again, with the Cunard White Star Liner ultimately posting {{convert|30.99|kn|km/h}} in 1938.<ref name=kludas /> ''Queen Mary’s'' consort, ''Queen Elizabeth'', was commissioned after war was declared and was never allowed to attempt the record.<ref name=gibbs />
In 1935, [[Harold Hales|Harold K. Hales]] (1868–1942), a member of the UK Parliament and owner of a shipping company, commissioned [[Hales Trophy|a large trophy]] to be presented to the fastest ship crossing the Atlantic, in order to formalize the rules surrounding the trans Atlantic competition. The rules for the trophy did not correspond to the traditional rules for the Blue Riband in that the trophy was to be awarded only to surface passenger ship achieving the fastest speed in the westbound direction.<ref name="Kludas p17"/> Other rule changes further complicated the situation, and eventually the trophy was awarded to just three Blue Riband holders; ''Rex'', in 1935, ''Normandie'' in 1936, and ''United States'' in 1952.
Of the ships of state, only ''Queen Mary'', ''Queen Elizabeth'' and ''Europa'' survived the war. ''Europa'' became CGT's ''Liberte'' and no attempt was made to retain her former speed when she was reconstructed.<ref name=gibbs /> However, the United States government was impressed by the large numbers of troops carried by the Queens during the war, and ordered a superliner that was as much a troop carrier as an express liner. On her maiden voyage in 1952, the [[SS United States|''United States'']] upped the Blue Riband to {{convert|34.51|kn|km/h}}. In 1958, the transatlantic airlines put jet transports into service and the days of the record breakers were numbered. ''Liberte'' retired in 1961, along with ''Queen Mary'' in 1967, and ''United States'' in 1969.<ref name=kludas />
===The Blue Riband today (1969–present)=== With the success of ''United States'' in 1952 and Cunard's decision not to challenge the new record the Blue Riband contest again subsided. There was a growing recognition that the era of fast crossings by express liners was becoming a thing of the past, and that the contest for fast transatlantic travel was shifting to the air.<ref name=Times8752>[http://find.galegroup.com/ttda/newspaperRetrieve.do?sgHitCountType=None&sort=DateAscend&tabID=T003&prodId=TTDA&resultListType=RESULT_LIST&searchId=R1&searchType=BasicSearchForm&currentPosition=13&qrySerId=Locale%28en%2C%2C%29%3AFQE%3D%28tx%2CNone%2C11%29Blue+Riband%3AAnd%3ALQE%3D%28da%2CNone%2C23%2901%2F01%2F1952+-+12%2F31%2F1952%3AAnd%3ALQE%3D%28MB%2CNone%2C8%29%22TTDA-1%22%24&retrieveFormat=MULTIPAGE_DOCUMENT&userGroupName=livlibtda&inPS=true&contentSet=LTO&&docId=&docLevel=FASCIMILE&workId=&relevancePageBatch=CS117919464&contentSet=UDVIN&callistoContentSet=UDVIN&docPage=article&hilite=y The Blue Riband]: Editorial, 8 July 1952, [[The Times]]; retrieved 31 July 12017</ref>
In the 1930s, air travel was already competing with the express liners for fast Atlantic crossings; in 1936 the German company DELAG commenced an airship service to New York, their [[LZ 129 Hindenburg|''Hindenburg'']] crossing from Europe to America in times ranging from 53 to 78 hours, and the following year, while experimenting with a flying boat service, Empire Airways [[Short Empire#Operational history|''Caledonia'']] reduced this to 15 hours. In the post-war period times were reduced again by the advent of land based airliners, such as the [[Lockheed Constellation]]. Hopes in 1952 were expressed for the new [[de Havilland Comet]] jetliner,<ref name=Times8752/> though these were dashed by [[de Havilland Comet#Early hull losses|the succession of crashes]] that halted the Comet programme. A regular jetliner service was finally introduced in 1958 with the [[Boeing 707]] and the [[Douglas DC-8|DC 8]], cutting the crossing to 7 hours. The final step in the quest for trans-Atlantic speed was the [[BAC Concorde]], which set a record in 1996 of a second under two hours 53 minutes, at an average speed of 1250 mph (Mach 1.9),<ref>[http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/news/60at60/2015/8/1996-fastest-flight-across-the-atlantic-in-a-commercial-aircraft-392882 1996: Fastest flight across the Atlantic in a commercial aircraft] at [[Guinness World Records]], retrieved 30 July 2017</ref> but by this time airlines were aware that cost and comfort were more important to passengers than speed, and the emphasis shifted to aircraft like the [[Boeing 747]], with a sleeper capacity for business passengers.
[[File:Gentry_Eagle.jpg|thumb|Tom Gentry's ''Gentry Eagle'' at Mamaroneck, New York, prior to a record attempt.]] At sea ''United States'' record stood until 1986, when it was challenged by British entrepreneur [[Richard Branson]], and his high-speed motor vessel, ''Virgin Atlantic Challenger''. Despite having to stop to refuel on several occasions, Branson shaved two hours off the record, increasing the average speed to 36.4 knots. However, as '' Virgin Atlantic Challenger'' was not a passenger vessel the New York Maritime Museum refused to part with the Hales Trophy, so Branson inaugurated the [[Virgin Atlantic Challenge Trophy]], for the fastest unqualified Atlantic crossing, open to all challengers. Three years later this was won by Tom Gentry, whose ''Gentry Eagle'' slashed the record, crossing in 62 hours at an average 47.4 knots. In 1992 the Virgin Atlantic Challenge was again won, by the [[Aga Khan]]'s ''[[Destriero]]'' crossing in 58 hour 34 minutes and averaging 53.09 knots. She also made a record-breaking return journey, winning the [[Columbus Atlantic Trophy]], posted by the yacht club in response to the Virgin Atlantic Challenge for the fastest two-way voyage i.e. a single crossing and return voyage within a specified time.
Meanwhile, [[Incat]], builders of fast catamaran ferries, and therefore indisputably commercial vessels, decided to make an attempt to win the Hales Trophy, for which the record was still that of ''United States''. This was achieved in 1990 by ''[[Hoverspeed Great Britain]]'', with a non-stop crossing of 79 hours 54 minutes, averaging 36.6 knots and Incat were awarded the trophy by the Hales Trophy Committee. Eight years later this record was broken by another Incat vessel, ''[[Catalonia (ship)|Catalonia]]'' and again the following month by ''[[Cat-Link V]]''.
The [[Ocean rowing|Ocean Rowing]] Society inspired by The Blue Riband concept created Blue Riband Trophy of Ocean Rowing awarded to the fastest crew to cross the Atlantic Ocean in an unsupported row boat. Presently it is the most sought after trophy of Ocean Rowing.<ref name="oceanrowing.com"/>
With the end of the express liners era the Blue Riband has become an item of largely historical interest, with some authors regarding the ''United States'' as the last holder of the accolade;<ref name=kludas /> meanwhile the goal of the fastest Atlantic crossings remains a physical and technological challenge and at least three awards for the feat remain in play.
==List of record breakers== The following is the latest consensus list of the research to date. Because there was no sanctioning body for the Blue Riband, researchers are limited to surviving shipping company archives and press reports to develop the list of Blue Riband winners. These lists are retrospective, and limited to steamships only. Therefore, most lists feature ''Sirius'', in her race with ''Great Western'' in 1838, as the first record-holder, although her crossing was not as fast as some sail packet ships of the period. Early writers including Arthur Maginnus (1892), Henry Frey (1896), Charles Lee (1931) and C. R. Benstead (1936) were the standard sources until the 1950s. Since then, C. R. Vernon Gibbs (1952),<ref name=gibbs /> and Noel Bonsor (1975) added to the body of knowledge, with additional detail about the German ships provided by Arnold Kludas.<ref name=kludas />
Over the years, the lists have not agreed. For example, Gibbs credits Inman's ''City of Paris'' with an 1866 Blue Riband voyage, and Cunard's ''Russia'' with an eastbound record the following year because he considered as dubious ''Scotia's'' Blue Riband claim of {{convert|14.46|kn|km/h}}, supposedly based on a very long track.<ref name=gibbs /> Later writers have included the ''Scotia'' claim.<ref name=kludas /> Gibbs also includes the claimed Blue Riband voyage at {{convert|17.6|kn|km/h}} of the National Line's ''America'' of 1884<ref name=gibbs /> that was not confirmed by later researchers.<ref name=kludas />

{{advert|date=April 2017}} {{Infobox non-profit |name = Business for Scotland |image = |image_border = |formation = 2012 |dissolution = |key_people = Gordon MacIntyre-Kemp, [[Richard Arkless]], Tony Banks,Councillor Niall John McLean, Graeme McCormick, Ian McDougall, Gillian O'Neill, Rob Aberdein, Jil Murphy, Donald Maclean, Kenny Anderson, Michelle Rodger, Michelle Thomson, David Cairns, Sandy Adam | focus = Scottish prosperity | mission = 'To champion progress towards the creation of a Scottish society and business community that provides greater opportunities for shared prosperity'
|budget = |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |website = {{URL|businessforscotland.co.uk}} | footnotes = }} '''Business for Scotland''' is a business network and business and economic policy think tank which seeks to give a voice to businesspeople who support [[Scottish independence]].<ref>[http://www.businessforscotland.co.uk/our-goal/ Our Goal] www.businessforscotland.co.uk, 14 May 2013</ref>
==Formation== Business for Scotland was founded by six Scottish business owners and directors, and generated over 250 members by word-of-mouth prior to the launch of its website. The organisation's membership had risen to 350 by the time of its official launch in May 2013, where it was publicly backed by [[Falklands War]] veteran and Scottish entrepreneur, [[Tony Banks (businessman)|Tony Banks]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.scotsman.com/news/uk/business-for-scotland-independence-group-launches-1-2927647|title=Business for Scotland independence group launches |work=[[The Scotsman]] |date=14 May 2013|accessdate=14 May 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-scotland-politics-22521342|title=Scottish referendum: Business leaders join new pro-independence group|date=14 May 2013|accessdate=14 May 2013|work=BBC News}}</ref> Business for Scotland membership at the time of the referendum was approximately 3,000.
== Prominent Business People == Tony Banks ([[Balhousie Care Group]]),<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/scottish-independence/11065467/Small-firms-making-big-claims-for-Scottish-independence.html|title=Small firms making big claims for Scottish independence|last=Gilligan|first=Andrew|date=2014-08-31|work=The Telegraph|access-date=2018-08-22|language=en-GB|issn=0307-1235}}</ref> Graeme McCormick (Conveyancing Direct), Ian McDougall (McDougall Johnstone/ The Glasgow Distillery),<ref name=":0" /> Gillian O'Neill ([[29 Studios]]), Rob Aberdein (Walker Morris), Jil Murphy (Thin Red Line/ Head of BfS Edinburgh), Donald Maclean (Business Cost Consultants), Kenny Anderson ([[Anderson Construction]]), Michelle Rodger ([[Tartan Cat]]/ Head of BfS Glasgow), David Cairns ([[PrismTech]]/ Head of BfS Perth), Sandy Adam (Springfield Properties), Brian Souter ([[Souter Investments]]). [[Jim Mather]], who was a member of the Scottish Parliament for the [[Scottish National Party]] (SNP) between 2003 and 2011, and served as [[Minister for Enterprise, Energy and Tourism]] under the 2007-11 SNP government, was a director at the organisation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bipsolutions.com/events/cbi-sbs2010/agenda_jimmather.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-02-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150203194239/http://www.bipsolutions.com/events/cbi-sbs2010/agenda_jimmather.html |archivedate=2015-02-03 |df= }} CBI, accessed 3 February 2015</ref><ref>[http://www.cifalscotland.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=152:presenter-biographies&catid=32:past-training-programmes&Itemid=47]{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} CIFAL, accessed 3 February 2015</ref>
==Scottish Referendum== Business for Scotland Ltd registered with the [[Electoral Commission]] as a "permitted participant" on the Yes side in the [[Scottish independence referendum, 2014]].<ref>[http://www.electoralcommission.org.uk/__data/assets/pdf_file/0007/169153/35-14-Response-for-web.pdf FoI response from Electoral Commission]</ref> It spent £143,027 campaigning at the independence referendum<ref>[http://www.electoralcommission.org.uk/i-am-a/journalist/electoral-commission-media-centre/news-releases-donations/electoral-commission-publishes-first-details-of-spending-by-campaigners-at-the-scottish-independence-referendum? ["Electoral Commission publishes first details of spending by campaigners at the Scottish independence referendum"] Electoral Commission news release published 3 February 2015</ref> making it the largest spender of the all the registered participant groups. After the referendum it was revealed that Business for Scotland received a £100,000 donation from Stagecoach founder Brain Souter.
The Founder and Chief Executive of the organisation, and registered responsible person with the electoral commission was Gordon MacIntyre-Kemp.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/news/15105527.Business_for_Scotland_boss_admits_losing_money_on_his_business/|title=Business for Scotland boss admits losing money on his business|last=Gordon|first=Tom|date=2017-02-21|website=Herald Scotland|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-08-22}}</ref> The organisation was chaired during the referendum by Tony Banks.
Pro Unionist blogger Kevin Hague<ref name=":0" /> put a complaint in to the [[Electoral Commission]] to consider whether the SNP and Business for Scotland had worked together during the Scottish referendum.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Sanderson|first1=Daniel|title=Electoral Commission to look at claims SNP broke indyref spending rules|url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/politics/13840098.Electoral_Commission_to_look_at_claims_SNP_broke_indyref_spending_rules/|accessdate=13 October 2015|publisher=HeraldScotland}}</ref> The Electoral Commission "found no evidence during its assessment that the SNP and BFS worked together" and consequently stated there was no need to open a full investigation into the allegations.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.electoralcommission.org.uk/i-am-a/journalist/electoral-commission-media-centre/news-releases-donations/electoral-commission-concludes-assessment-of-allegations-against-business-for-scotland-and-the-scottish-national-party |title=Electoral Commission concludes assessment of allegations against Business for Scotland and the Scottish National Party |work= |publisher=Electoral Commission |date=15 October 2015 |accessdate=15 October 2015}}</ref> This was reported in the Herald that the Electoral Commission gave the accusations extremely short shrift. [http://www.heraldscotland.com/business/13876824.Revenge_sweet_for_BfS_as____troll____back_in_his_boxTurkish_delight_in_flight_plan/]
In 2017 a pro-union Scottish Business UK group was set up by Scottish businesses to argue against independence in opposition to Business for Scotland.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/aa4fd87e-a47b-11e7-9e4f-7f5e6a7c98a2|title=Scottish business group steps up plans to oppose referendum|last=Dickie|first=Mure|date=2017-09-30|website=Financial Times|language=en-GB|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-08-22}}</ref>
==Membership== By March 2014, membership of the organisation was claimed to be in excess of 1300.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.businessforscotland.co.uk/member-profiles/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-03-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140302202528/http://www.businessforscotland.co.uk/member-profiles/ |archivedate=2014-03-02 |df= }} businessforscotland.co.uk, accessed 1 March 2014</ref> As of July 2017 the membership of the organisation was claimed to be 4,000.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.sie.ac.uk/head-of-business-for-scotland-joins-speakers-at-bios-conference/|title=Head of business for Scotland joins speakers at bios conference!|last=|first=|date=2016-10-05|website=Scottish Institute for Enterprise|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-08-22}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.scotsman.com/news/independence-offers-business-opportunity-of-a-lifetime-1-4518043|title=Independence offers ‘business opportunity of a lifetime’|last=King|first=Diana|date=2017-07-31|work=The Scotsman|access-date=2018-08-22|language=en}}</ref>
==Company Formation== Business for Scotland, SC430989, was first registered on 23 August 2012 by a sole director named as Gordon MacIntyre-Kemp. It is registered as a private, limited by guarantee, company, with no shareholdings.
